awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: PERMIT: Privacy-Enabled Resource Management for IoT Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates how privacy can be used to inform the design and management of future data sensing systems. Networked systems that collect data about individuals will play an increasingly important role in our lives, with applications including industrial monitoring and control, "smart" homes/cities, and personalized health care. These systems will gather private information about individuals, which creates many coupled engineering challenges. This work seeks to understand the interplay between two of these: managing the massive amounts of data that must be collected and protecting the privacy of individuals in the system. For applications or services that rely on populations of individuals, reducing the amount of information transmitted can save bandwith while enhancing privacy. The objectives of this work are to use ideas from data privacy technologies and wireless resource management techniques to jointly manage privacy and bandwidth in wireless sensing systems.

The technical objectives of this project involve reformulating distributed data collection and estimation problems under privacy constraints in wireless network settings. Differential privacy gives a framework for quantifying the privacy risk of different strategies for compression and data reduction, leading to a privacy-bandwidth-quality tradeoff. At the system level, total privacy risk is a resource that can be managed; this project uses that insight to design novel privacy-allocation schemes. Ultimately, this project seeks to formulate new tradeoffs between privacy and quality-of-service that can generalize to other networking problems. To see how these approaches work in practice, this work involves prototyping and testing the methods in a wireless networking testbed.

por.por_cntn:
The number of networked devices has increased tremendously in the last decade and this trend is expected to continue as we embed sensing and communication capabilities into consumer devices, infrastructures, industrial monitoring systems, and personal healthcare. This ubiquitous sensing and data collection comes with a clear cost to indvidual privacy as we are increasingly surveilled: this a the dark side to the Internet of Things (IoT). It is well known from several studies that devices "leak" information and that by observing the data a device generates we can infer the type of device, what it sensed, and when it sensed it. Such inferences are even possible by looking at the network traffic generated by the device, such as packet sizes and timings, without looking at the sensor data itself.

There many different ways to think about "privacy" in the context of these networked systems. We assume there is an adversary who can observe the output of a system and wants to infer things about the input. For example, in studies on anonymity, the adversary wants to understand which parties are communicating with each other. We are interested in preventing an adversary from inferring if a particular event has occured. In a prototypical IoT architecture, a gateway system manages IoT devices (e.g., embedded sensors) that need to send data to an application server on the Internet. This research focused on understanding how to prevent an adversary from inferring when an event happened based on observing the network traffic leaving the gateway. In particular, we focused on questions of what the adversary can learn and how to modify networking elements to limit what the adversary can learn. We envision a future in which device owners may set more stringent privacy policies locally, which in turn has interesting ramifications for networking.

We contend that enforcing local privacy constraints inverts the traditional approach to networking IoT devices: rather than being bandwidth-hungry and competing for the wireless channel, privacy-enabled devices wish to limit the amount of data sent to the server, thereby promoting more efficient sharing of network bandwidth. This, however, runs the risk of starving the application whose functioning (utility) depends upon the availability of sensor data, which yields interesting tradeoffs between privacy, bandwidth, and utility.

There were three main components to this project looking at different parts of IoT systems. First, we examined how sensors might modify their own observations to mask inferences about events they might be sensing. This can be done by randomly perturbing the measured values. In order to get meaningful privacy levels the perturbation has to be signficant, which is tolerable only in a few applications. In the second part of the project we looked at the network traffic leaving the gateway. Currently used IoT devices generate very unique traffic: based on the timing and size of packets, we can infer a lot about what events were being observed/sensed by the device. We proposed a unififed framework for how traffic shaping can be used to provide quantifiable privacy. We used the differential privacy framework for quantifying privacy risk and showed how the gateway can manipulate the outgoing traffic to partially mask what events are occuring from an adversary. "Perfect" privacy comes at a cost in terms of additonal delay and excess bandwidth. By relaxing the privacy guarantee we can see improvements under both measures. The final part of the project looked at how a gateway should manage the traffc coming from dfferent devices through rate allocaton. Again, perfect privacy comes at a cost in terms of efficiency. Our work examined how to provide private and fair rate allocations to devices competing for the use of a communication link. In this settng, privacy is a resource, like delay and bandwidth, that must be managed by the gateway system.

Intellectual Merit: This project brought the use of differential privacy into the analysis of communication and networking systems. The way in which data is collected and transmtted is quite diffrent from the standard setup under differential privacy. The insights from this research suggest that increased standardization of IoT networking protocols can help mitgate informaton leakage due to the network traffic.

Broader Impact: This work has initiated a conversation between networking and privacy research that we anticipate will grow over time. In addition to supporting the education and research of several graduate students, this project helped in the development of tutorial materials on differential privacy in the form of talks and a short course. The experimental evaluation of our traffic shaping mechanism opens the door to further prototypng and development of new networking protocols to handle IoT traffic.
